WRITING.TEXT: Of course this is a highly opinionated statement and only accounts for games that I have played. No need to get your panties in a twist.

Horizon's story is second to only The Last of Us (for a video game story).
I beat it yesterday and I was completely floored by it.
I noticed some heroes don't have a score yet, what's up with that?

How much meta data do you get? Winrate per hero is one thing, but I would think a lot more information is necessary to give an accurate score. It would be cool to have like average score in dominion or something.

Well, the changes/buffs in this patch were *mainly* bug fixes (aside from Valk) and fixing unintentional mechanics like Zerk and Conqs light recovery. They probably want to wait and collect more data/do more creative thinking about how to balance all the other characters than make hasty decisions and change everything at once. They are being smart. This patch is fine, save your bitching for when something is actually worth bitching about.
Wat
Every game in the history of games has had servers go down.

Like this
https://youtu.be/A7LwQjhpZ-g
I think all maps have a ledge somewhere at least, but most can be easily avoided. Only a couple maps have a small amount of space to maneuver.
I want dunkey to review every game.
Fair points, I imagine esports would probably ban the maps that are nothing but ledge kills.
You try and push a skilled player off a cliff and you'll be the one falling. There's still skill involved and it's very high risk

I was in a 1v1 on a map with easy ledge kills, I kept trying to pull the fight away the ledge so we couldn't do that, but he determined to stay there. I ran at him and kicked him off. I said in chat "you made me do it." HE replied "I know T_T" and he never went by the edge again.

Environment kills may seem cheesy (they kinda are), but they are also very exciting imo. When you get better at countering guard break you don't have to worry as much. But sometimes you're in a map with easy ledge drops and both players know exactly what the other is going to try to do. You can see it on their faces. Playing around this is, imo, exciting and can go both ways.

For me, in these kinds of games, the "progression" is just getting good. The drive to improve and learn game mechanics and better as a player is all the progression I need. I'm sure it's the same for the majority of players. What gear progression they do have is just cook for adding small tweaks to your 4v4 playstyle. Nothing major.
Vsauce's show is pretty fun.
Because if you have a bot on your team, you lose.

WRITING.TITLE: Please stop filling Deathmatch with bots, Ubisoft
WRITING.TEXT: There's no join in progress for Deathmatch, but I keep getting matches where MM puts bots on one side. Not even split them up, they'll be two on one side and none on the other. WTF, just wait a minute and use people please.
Sometimes it really helps to think about something for a few seconds before you speak. I consider that a crucial quality that I learned in life. I'm sure you'll get there.
Thanks for reading past the the first half of my post. It was the big point i was trying to make. Didn't think everyone would get so worked up with the specifics of how op the ship is.

"I can both try to play optimally and criticise what WG made the optimal choice to be. Hate the game, not the player."
-/u/Roflkopt3r
A unicum Belfast player will outplay every other ship.

I have given fair points as refute against these hard counters. Your refusal to address them is not an invalidation.
This is true of every ship in the game.
Tell that to a DD vs a radar cruiser.

* Often Belfasts will be undetected prior to slowing down for their smoke. It's poor play on the Belfast's part otherwise.
* As I've stated elsewhere, forcing a Belfast out of their smoke is effective, but it's not a counter. With its 8.7km detection, being able to quietly relocate when threatened is strength, not a weakness. A luxury many ships don't have.
* Shooting into smoke requires a bit of RNG because your dispersion is so poor. Also a good Belfast player might be moving.
* CVs need to be played more, I agree. CV is a counter to Belfast.
* A good Belfast player won't let a BB rush their smoke. They should see this coming way before its too late and, as stated above, being able to quietly relocate (8.7km detection) is not a weakness.

Being able to disengage quietly and relocate is not a weakness. Many ships don't get such a luxury. Forcing a Belfast to go quiet for a minute or so and get a better position is not a soft kill, it's good play from the Belfast and it's plays like that that often win games.

It's worth pointing out that being pushed off a cap or forced to disengage without doing damage is something that is universal across all classes. Any other cruiser that doesn't have smoke will have to disengage simply if a BB starts looking at them. Any DD trying to cap can get forced out by the enemy team getting too close. Unless a BB manages to sneak up on a Belfast smoke, they will be spotted from however far out. I've had Scharnhorst try and charge but hell, they are going to lose half their HP before they even reach the smoke. If you look at ranked seasons in the past, there are certainly strong ships that get played the most, every tier will have them. But you look at ranked this season and its Belfast that beats everything. With good play, a Belfast will never be hard countered.

But that's exactly my point. The way to beat it is just playing a better Belfast. This is not okay and this is something that shouldn't exist. It's not fun, it's not balanced gameplay. And it's Wargaming's stance on nerfing premiums that brings up very real issues with the game's direction (which was most of the point of my post). If Wargaming refuses to take the hit on nerfing a premium for the benefit of their game, it shows their attitude at how they care about balance. You cannot simply accept the fate of the ship behind Wargaming's own policies as they are not there for anyone's benefit but Wargaming's. Contrary to the response I've been getting in this thread, I know that I'm not the only one concerned with their current direction. When ranked was announced for T7, I saw loads of contention about how Wargaming pushes OP premiums at T7 and how they know exactly what they are doing.

I'd argue that most of these "counters" simply involve delaying the Belfasy's potential and not stopping it. Sure a charging BB or a torp wall might force you to leave but you can just relocate with your 8.7km detection and start over. You have 4 smokes on a fast cooldown.

With 8.7km detection and a half decent amount of game sense, no Belfast player worth his salt will let a BB charge them. If such a threat seems like it might happen, you can just leave your smoke before they get within your detection.

If they balance around server wide stats, it's clear the Belfast is one of the strongest ships in the game. In fact, most of the other ships that perform about as well (stat wise) are all niche premiums being played by a small group of mostly skilled players or ships that have qualified as OP and are no longer for sale. It's the one ship with the most matches played in the top ships of 2 weeks while the others fit the criteria I listed above. With its increased amount of matches, we can assume that it's not just mostly skilled players in it, but a good mix of everyone.
The ships that are best in competitive simply perform well for the meta and with team play. Their strengths are ideal for the type of gameplay that competitive brings out but on their own this does not make them OP. Belfast is a ship outperforms all other competition on its own and it really requires a team effort to take down just a single one. It's also worth pointing out that in competitive play, there are numerous good ships. By the state of ranked, it's clear that Belfast doesn't simply outclass other cruisers, but every other ship class as well.

You cannot balance a game on the low skilled players. The most successful games balance around high skill play. But this goes back to the point I made in the post about the only thing that counters it is itself. Can you dispute this? Because that is the crux of the issue and just because a better Belfast player will beat a worse one does not a balanced ship make.
You have summarized ranked this season. Play Belfast and do it better than the other team. It's the only viable strat.
I understand that, and I addressed that sentiment in this post.
The prospect of "is only as good as the player using it" can be applied to every ship, OP or not.
And Belfast has hydro so you see them coming then zip out with your turbo boost acceleration.

WRITING.TITLE: What it is that makes a ship over powered and War Gaming's purposeful negligence.
WRITING.TEXT:
With the current state of ranked play and with the upcoming release of the USS Black and prospects of the future of Warships, I'd like to bring this discussion to you guys.
I've been playing competitive games for a long time and I've been playing Warships for 2 years now. I've seen all kinds of things that are OP to things that people want to be OP and others that people think are OP but are not. Something that I think a lot of people misunderstand when looking at game balance is the idea that something that is strong is not necessarily over powered. In fact, I would argue that good balance requires some things to be strong for their purpose to be able to bring good diversity to the gameplay.
Let's look at some ships more specifically that I think fit this role. The first ship that comes to mind is the Yamato. This is a ship that can tank every other BB while punishing those that try to tank it. Is this OP? Well no, it's certainly strong, but other elements like cruiser fire and torps keep it grounded (so to speak). What bout Moskva? That's a ship that is long considered OP but again I would argue that just because it is good at its job (bow tanking enemy fire) there are still ways to shut it down. Moskva can get overrun very easily, its bow overmatched, and once its engaged it has basically no way of disengaging.
So what do these two strong ships have in common? There are ways to counter them. There is interaction that minimizes their effectiveness. This is the core principle of what can be considered balance. And it's also why (I assume) stealth firing is under scrutiny from WG. Stealth firing is a mechanic that has little interaction and in some cases, little to no way of countering. This is why it is imbalanced.
But then again, stealth firing is a problem mechanic in the game and shouldn't really reflect the balance of whatever ship takes advantage of it.
**Through all my years of playing multiplayer games, there is a SINGLE tell-tale sign of something that is way overpowered: it's only counter is itself.**
BELFAST SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE GAME.
(or at least least nerfed)
Ranked has brought this prospect back into my perspective in an infuriating way. Here we have a meta that is dominated by smoke. Okay. Fine. Smoke is strong but there are ways to counter it, right? At higher tiers, sure. Long range radar, long range hydro, and long range torps do it well enough. But at T7? The only radar that exists (is on premiums) is very short range and getting into that range is tricky. Unless you're a Belfast with 8.7km detection and smoke of its own. So, the only viable radar counter to this heavy smoke meta is the smoke meta king himself, the Belfast.
BBs don't counter it: you can't hit what you can't see (generally). DDs don't counter it: 10km torps require you to get dangerously close to their radar and lololol Belfast has hydro and super acceleration. So, in the end, the only actual counter to Belfast is another Belfast.
The existence of this ship in the game is incredibly troubling. Wargaming doesn't nerf premiums for understandable reasons (money backlash), but that is THEIR issue. Belfast being in this game is OUR issue and if they refuse to address that for their own benefit, I would be vary weary of continuing any support for this developer. I've defended Wargaming on many occasions and many dumb decisions. Most of the time they got it right eventually. But this is really unacceptable for any developer that claims to care about their game and their customers over their own bottom line. Be careful watching these guys moving forward. Their intentions are becoming more and more clear. I hope they prove me wrong, but with ranked being T7 this time and the current state of T7 premiums, it's hard to assume otherwise. Until then, I think it's time I found another game to play.
Nah we had the Atlanta and Ranger to their Flint and Hiryu. The CV walked all over us once all the smoke started dissipating.
Turns out, most of those smokes have radar too.
6 smokes per side. 6 Belfast. Zero ways to counter any of it.

WRITING.TITLE: I wish Madhouse was available from the start. :(
WRITING.TEXT:
Kinda shitty imo.
I usually play games on the hardest difficulty for the challenge. The extra layer of difficulty *usually* adds to the experience and satisfaction of beating a game. This goes doubly so for a survival horror game like RE7, where tension is high and the task at hand seems impossible which *should* be matched by the difficulty. Well I just beat the game on Normal and I wasn't even aware of the Madhouse difficulty as it popped up and told me I had unlocked it. I enjoyed the game a lot but it was not a difficult game. Now I have this extra difficulty and reading up on it, it seems like exactly how the game should have been play the FIRST run through. That playthrough where you're still figuring out what is even going on. What are enemy's weaknesses? Where do I go? What are even the coins for!? Because experiencing all that on top of the mechanics of Madhouse would have been a TRULY terrifying and nail biting experience. When you FINALLY get to that safe zone with 1 HP and 1 bullet and you're *holy fucking shit man that was close*. And it's how the game should have been played from the start. These types of games I usually just play once and then maybe again later when it's not so fresh on the mind. So I feel very gibbed.
tl;dr - why the fuck do devs lock difficulties behind completion?
/rant

Well, "should be criminal" may be a bit of a stretch but it doesn't make much sense for multi million/billion $ businesses to pay literally pennies on the penny when everyone else is forking over large % of their salary. You always struck me the type to read the first sentence and presume the rest.
Kudos to you for cherry picking your arguments.

We were aggressive early and lost the fight. Should this be the end of the match? Perhaps all games of bastion should last only 5 minutes, the victor decided by who holds the caps at the time. This would certainly relive many the displeasure of playing the mode further, but I fail to see to depth and reason of such an implementation. Domination already offers a similar advantage and strategy for the early game, but implores also a mid game and late game that continue to evolve strategy. Bastion offers nothing that isn't already offered in other game modes and yet brings nothing new.

It was the version that has two forts in the mid, our team capped one and theirs the other. Then their fort killed our DDs from our fort, which allowed them to take both. Taking them back was a futile effort and you can see just how much of input their actual team had on the situation.
